details.title: A general repair, proportional-hazards, framework to model complex repairable systems
details.standardTitle: A general repair, proportional-hazards, framework to model complex repairable systems

p: Sofiane Gasmi earned the M.Sc. in Mathematics in 1995 from the Otto-von-Guericke University of Magdeburg, Germany. Since 1996 he has been at the Department of Mathematics, Otto-von-Guericke University, Magdeburg. His research interests are in the reliability of stochastic systems; he has published in international journals on these issues.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math., Otto-von-Guericke Univ. of Magdeburg, Germany
authors.name: S. Gasmi

p: C. Ernie Love obtained the B.Eng. (chemical) in 1966 from McMaster University, the M.BA. in 1969 from McMaster University, and the Ph.D. in 1975 in Operations Research from the University of London. His research interests are in the analysis of stochastic systems; he has been published in a variety of international journals on these issues. Prior to obtaining his Ph.D., Dr. Love worked as an engineer for Shell Oil Company and Union Carbide Ltd.

Waltraud Kahle earned the M.Sc. in Mathematics in 1976 from State University Rostov (Russia), the Ph.D. in 1979 from Technical University Riga (Latvia) and habilitation in 1991 from University Magdeburg. Her research interests are in statistical methods related to reliability data. She has a particular interest in predicting “first passage times” for data without failure; she has been published in a variety of international journals. She is an Associate Professor in the Department of Mathematics, Otto-von-Guericke University, Magdeburg.

details.abstract: A system (machine) is observed to operate in 1 of 2 modes. The most common mode is loaded (or regular) operation. Occasionally the system is placed in an unloaded state, wherein while the system is mechanically still operating, it is assumed that the failure intensity is lower due to this reduction in operating intensity. A proportional hazards framework is used to capture this potential reduction in failure intensity due to switching of operating modes. In either operating condition, analyzed maintenance-records indicate that the system was occasionally shut down, and either a minor or a major repair was undertaken. Furthermore, despite such repairs, it is observed that both modes of operation (loaded or unloaded) resulted in random failures. On failure, 1 of 3 actions are taken: (1) failures were minimally repaired, (2) given a minor repair, or (3) given a major repair. Both minor and major repairs are assumed to impact the intensity following a virtual age process of the general form proposed by Kijima. This research develops a statistical model of such an operating/maintenance environment. Its purpose is to quantify the impacts of performing these repair actions on the failure intensities. Field data from an industrial-setting demonstrate that appropriate parameter estimates for such multiple phenomena can be obtained. Providing a richer, more detailed, modeling of the failure intensity of a system incorporating both operating conditions and repair effects has important ramifications for maintenance planning. This paper refers to related research, in which optimal timing of maintenance repairs depends fundamentally on the failure rate of the system.

context.text: Reference [4]proposes that the state of the machine just after repair can be described by its virtual age which is smaller (younger) than the real age; in this framework, the failure rate depends on the virtual age of the system.
Reference [4]suggests 2 repair-effect models.

references.text: M. Kijima, H. Morimura, Y. Suzuki, "Periodical replacement problem without assuming minimal repair", Eur. J. Oper. Res., vol. 37, pp. 194-203, 1988.

context.text: Model #2 assumes that the repair action could remove all damage accumulated up to that point in time (a KT2 virtual age process); i.e., such repairs reset the virtual age of the unit to somewhere between that of a completely restored unit (good-as-new repair) and a minimally repaired unit [6].

references.title: Mathematical Theory of Reliability
references.text: R. E. Barlow, F. Proschan, Mathematical Theory of Reliability, 1965, John Wiley.

context.text: The concept of minimal repair upon failure is well understood in the literature [7]–[9], and the resultant nonhomogeneous Poisson process has been applied extensively to describe the operation of repairable systems.

context.text: KT2 processes provide a more general framework for the modeling of the repair process [10], [11].

Unlike the more typical treatments in the literature [10], [11] it is not assumed in this research that minor or major repairs served to reset the failure intensity of the system (a good-as-new repair).

context.text: After repair, the failure intensity during sojourn \$\#(k+1)\$ is determined by The process defined by \$v(t,\, \xi_1,\, \xi_2) = t - t_k + v_k\$, \$t_k \leq t<t_{k+1}\$, \$k \geq 0\$ is the “virtual age process” [12].

links.abstract: It is common for residual lifetimes to be either discarded or treated as if they were right-censored data estimating two-parameter Weibull distributions. The exact maximum likelihood (ML) estimators for dealing with sampled data with residual lifetimes are formulated. Monte Carlo simulation is used to compare the performance of ML estimators for various approaches to the treatment of residual data. Two types of LS (least squares) estimators are also evaluated: LSMR (LS median rank) estimators an...

context.text: While estimation procedures have been suggested for residual lifetimes [15] using data on multiple copies of a system, the system in this paper is a single copy (a single machine), where the initial running time of the system, prior to data being recorded, is not known. (A typical situation for many large systems operating over many years.) Thus let \$v_0\$ be known, and all other parameters are of interest.

references.title: Estimators of 2-parameter Weibull distributions from incomplete data with residual lifetimes
references.text: A. H. C. Tsang, A. K. S. Jardine, "Estimators of 2-parameter Weibull distributions from incomplete data with residual lifetimes", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 42, no. 2, pp. 291-298, Jun. 1993.

context.text:
It is well known (e.g., [16], [17]), that in general the LL ratio is asymptotically \$\chi^2\$-distributed with \$k\$ degrees of freedom, \$k\$ is the number of parameters of interest,


\$\mathhat{\theta}\$ is the MLE of all parameters,

\$\theta\$ is the MLE of the nuisance parameters if the parameters of interest are fixed.

context.text: Last, to evaluate further the quality of the model, a set of standardized esiduals with estimated parameters were calculated [18]: pp. 279–282 for every observed sojourn:When the data are censored, the corresponding residuals are censored as well.

The estimate is defined as [18]: pp. 279–282: there are observations on \$N\$ sojourns and there are \$j (j\leq N)\$ distinct residuals associated with failures, ordered as: \$s_1 < s_2 < \cdots < s_j\$.

context.text: This model, while certainly more complex than prior reliability models in the literature, is quite straightforward to use in maintenance planning analysis [19], [20].
In [19], [20] the structure of imperfect repair has been used to determine optimal maintenance times, using semi-Markov and Markov structures.
In [19], [20], only 1 level of repair is used.
